story:
Thanks for visiting my page!

Cancer is something I always hoped would never affect any of my family or friends and I naively thought it never would. With 1 in 2 people in the UK being diagnosed with cancer within their lifetime, that statistic became even more real for my family this year.

In aid of Macmillan, and to show my appreciation for all of the support they have given to my family and thousands of others across the UK, I will be running 160 miles within the next three months before completing a half marathon at the end of February. 

Without our support, charities such as Macmillan would not be able to continue to provide their help to the people who really need it. 

Any donations are greatly appreciated! I will be posting progress updates at the bottom of the page.

Cheers, 

Jim

story:
Its nearly one year from I received my diagnosis of Breast Cancer.  Today I am in recovery after surgery and many months of treatment.  Macmillan were amazing in supporting me through this very difficult time.  I personally found living with cancer in the middle of a global pandemic very trying!!!  Macmillan were there to offer me all sorts of advice practically, emotionally, and physically.  I honestly would have been lost without them. x

The Christmas lights is something we do as a family every year, and we always choose a different charity to support.  This year I’ve chosen Macmillan because of my own personal experience.  They hold a very special place in my heart, and I would like to give something back.

On Friday 11th Dec from 5:30pm we will be hosting a Christmas drive-by with Santa all donations will be in aid of Macmillan Cancer Support.  If you cannot make this event, I would be very grateful if you could help me raise such vital funds to this very special charity.  

 From the bottom of my heart, Thankyou.,

Colette x

As a charity with a long history of serving humanity, we are proud of our past, our role in the pandemic and excited about creating a healthier, safer, brighter and more resilient future.

This winter may be our toughest yet and I am helping to bring some community spirit by sharing my sparkle by supporting St John. 

St John volunteers treat and transport thousands of patients each year, and in times of crisis we are England's national health reserve.  

During the pandemic our skilled and highly trained volunteers are working long shifts supporting sick people and their families, in hospitals, in ambulances and at home. We are proud to be working alongside the nations ambulance trusts and in hospitals around the country.

story:
I am raising money in aid of British Heart Foundation, a
charity which is very close to mine and my family's heart.

In June this year, 2020, our lives were flipped upside down.

My husband, then 31, fit, healthy, no medical history,
suffered a Sudden Cardiac Arrest in his sleep. After performing CPR, and following the quick response of the paramedics, they managed to stabilise him.

Ashley was then taken to Northampton General Hospital where
he was in a coma for a week. Various tests were done to determine why this had even happened?! They could find no reason...

Following this, the Cardiologist decided that fitting him
with an ICD (defibrillator) was the best option as a precautionary measure.

Ashley has recovered with some short term memory loss but is
doing absolutely amazing, leading a normal life.

The British Heart Foundation need more than ever, funding
for research into the causes, diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of heart and
circulatory diseases.

The coronavirus has cut ability to fund new research in
half, but heart and circulatory diseases are still the world’s biggest killers.
As we face the biggest crisis in our history, the British Heart Foundation urgently need our support.

This Charity means the world to myself & family, and I
thank you in advance for your contribution to this cause.

story: As many of you may know, after giving birth to Freddie in May he was transferred to Great Ormand Street at just 10 hours old. He was suffering from high output heart failure caused by his hemangioma. He was cared for in the paediatric intensive care unit for 10 days then we were moved onto a ward for the further 7 days before being allowed home. During our time at GOSH, Freddie was cared for by some of the most amazing consultants, doctors, nurses, physio's and specialists. His team worked tirelessly to stabilise his heart and help him adjust to life outside of the womb. I'm taking part in this challenge to run 31 miles in January to say thank you to all of the people who cared for Freddie and supported Jack and I during our time at GOSH. I can not run for toffee and at the moment, probably couldn't even run half a mile! I've also realised the logistics of getting the time to run with 2 young children so decided that Freddie will be doing this with me, albeit from the comfort of his buggy! After all, it's because of him that we were exposed to the care GOSH offers. I know its a tough time for everyone so any donation, big or small, will be greatly appreciated. Thank you x

Since lockdown began in March 2020 I have been training; cycling a minimum of 200km a week. Initially I wanted to use this time to improve my fitness and mental health, and as I improved I started taking on more challenges. 12 weeks ago I signed up to a virtual training programme on Zwift which ends just before Christmas. This will be a distance greater than I have ever cycled in one week, but I am confident that I can do it, with the inspiration of those I know who have completed or only just started their treatment this year. On behalf of all those people supported by this wonderful charity, I hope that you will consider sponsoring me in my efforts. I will provide regular updates throughout the week, and if you’re unable to sponsor me, I will still be very grateful for your words of encouragement!

rememberedPersonSummary.name: Rodney Hammond
story:
My dear late husband Rodney was diagnosed with late on-set Alzheimers in early 2017 with symptoms showing from a couple of years prior. His Alzheimers was fast progressing and very aggressive. After a few long painful years of watching him quickly deteriorate and after him taking a turn for the worst after a seizure at the start of November, we were told by the doctors on the 20th of November that they would be coming to make him comfortable for his last few days. 

We were having careers come in to help a couple of times a day and they mentioned that Marie Curie nurses could be organised to come and stay over night whilst Rod was having end of life care. This was soon organised and they sorted for somebody to stay for 3 nights. This came as a big relief to me as it meant I could go and get some rest over night knowing that he was in safe hands downstairs and someone was with him at all times. All 3 nights, the nurses phoned at 8 to make sure everything was ok and to even see if i wanted anything brought over! 

On the 4th night, we knew he was near the end so I phoned to see if someone could come and stay again as I was worried about him passing in the night by himself. The organiser that I spoke to said that we wasn't supposed to have a 4th night but phoned back later to say she had organised for someone to come as she felt sorry for me, all out of the kindness of her heart. As usual, the nurse that was coming phoned me at 8 to make sure everything was ok before she came but his breathing had changed by then. When I told her this, she said that she would be arriving early. At 9 o'clock, Rod sadly passed away surrounded by me and our son and daughter. 15 minutes after he had passed, the marie curie nurse arrived. Instead of leaving, she came in and changed him into his comfy pajamas and made sure he was clean. She then sat with us and comforted us whilst we waited for the doctor and under taker to arrive. She was an absolute God send that night, she kept us calm and stayed with us when she didn't really need to. Since Rod has passed, I have even had phone calls and flowers from the nurses.

I have chosen to fund raise for Marie Curie because not only did they come to just do their job of sitting with Rod over night, they were a great help and were so kind to me. What they do is absolutely incredible, giving families who are going through so much, some relief and comfort and I would like to give something back to them as I can't thank them enough for what they did for me and my family.

story:
Too many people are still drowning. More than ever we need the RNLI’s help. As a charity, the RNLI depends on our donations so it can go on saving lives and keeping us and our loved ones safe. RNLI lifesavers are our lifeline. They’re the lifeboat crews who provide 24-hour search and rescue right around the UK and Ireland. The lifeguards keeping watch on 240 of the busiest beaches in the UK and Channel Islands. And the RNLI safety teams and educators working tirelessly to stop people getting into trouble in the first place.

We thought long and hard what we wanted for Christmas but couldn't come up with anything worthwhile. So we decided, in lieu of Christmas presents this year, to ask for donations for the RNLI. With the year we have had they are struggling with funds and we thought we could help out so that they could keep on doing the fantastic work they do. We don't want you wandering round shops, mixing with large crowds, looking for something for us and thought this was a better way to go.

Stay safe and thank you.

Nature has been a gift to offer us comfort and much-needed escape during difficult times, and now it’s our time to give back. story:
Please donate £1 to UNICEF to wear your Christmas jumper this Friday!

As a Rights Respecting School we would like to raise funds for UNICEF and due to the Outright campaign we are currently participating in we have a special interest in the effects that Climate Change has had on children all over the world. 

Climate change puts children’s most basic rights at risk, seriously affecting their access to health, food, water, clean air, education and protection. Around the world, the growing number of extreme weather events is putting more and more children’s live’s in danger. Every year, environmental factors take the lives of 1.7 million children under five.

For an even greater number of children, these events mean a reduced chance of a happy, healthy future. When floods hit, schools and health clinics are destroyed. When droughts occur, children spend less time in school because they have to walk miles to collect water. Rising sea levels and toxic air pollution turn children’s communities into hazardous environments to grow up in.

These aren’t problems that can wait. They are problems right now, and Unicef is working tirelessly to help solve them.

Here at Oscott Manor we are hoping to raise one pound per child on Friday 11th December when we all have a lot of fun by wearing our Christmas jumpers and getting into the festive spirit. 

Many thanks for taking the time to read our story and donating if you feel able.

story:
We are fundraising because Unicef urgently need funds to expand the scale and scope of their work supporting children affected by coronavirus, especially in countries with weaker health systems.

£30 could provide a full kit to protect a health-worker on the frontline, including gloves, masks and coveralls, while just £43 could help provide 1,680 pairs of disposable gloves for health workers.

The impact of a large-scale outbreak of coronavirus on children, especially poor and vulnerable children, has been immense. Children are at risk from the disease, but also from the disruption to health and education services, impacts on caregivers, and separation from family members.

Unicef has been working closely with governments and the World Health Organization (WHO) since the start of the coronavirus outbreak. Donations made to my page will help to limit the spread of the virus and reduce the impact on children and families.

story:
As a self-employed dance Principal of dance schools suffering through covid-19 in 2 different countries, under 2 completely different sets of guidance we have struggled. Living abroad, me and my children have not seen some family members for over a year because of this pandemic and our lives have suffered as a result. 

BUT...

we have a roof over our heads, safety, comfort, a loving family, the technology to be able to connect with family and friends via the internet, multiple devices for homeschooling and working at home.

We have food, health and happiness. 

This is so much more than others have. 

Covid-19 aside, there are so many people in so many countries suffering EVERY DAY from things that we are so lucky (again) to not experience all the time. 

Their normal is our abhorrence and whilst we cannot stop it, we can help it by supporting services like 'Doctors without Borders" who continue to fight and help people in the most needed areas every day. No matter the risk. 

Please join me in this Week of Kindness (which I plan to continue further) to help support those that need so much more than we do. Our struggles are real and valid but that doesn't mean others don't need our help even more!

story: WaterAid is working to make clean water, decent toilets and good hygiene normal for everyone, everywhere within a generation. The international not-for-profit organisation works in 28 countries to change the lives of the poorest and most marginalised people. Since 1981, WaterAid has reached 26.4 million people with clean water and 26.3 million people with decent toilets.

story: I am challenging myself to drink nothing but water this January. I am taking on the ultimate detox by avoiding caffeine, alcohol and all other drinks while supporting WaterAid. Give before 4 February 2021 and your donation will be doubled by the UK government, up to £2 million, making double the difference in communities across Ethiopia. Together, we will bring clean water to 50,000 people in Ethiopia and thousands more around the world, helping them change their own lives, forever. If you would like further information about the difference your gift will make and the positive impact it will have on peoples lives, please visit us at www.wateraid.org/uk
